descriptions.content:
Verbs followed by the nominalizer ཡག་ indicate the present, future, or imperfective past according to the context. Furthermore, they often convey a sense of obligation (deontic sense).

The nominalizer ཡག་ is used to form nominal and relative clauses. It has two basic functions that should be distinguished from each other:

1. The nominalizer indicates the grammatical patient of the verbal action (the object of a transitive verb or the subject of an intransitive verb) in the present and future. From a syntactic point of view, the nominalized verb functions here as a head noun or as a modiﬁer of the head noun, and may often be translated in English by using a relative clause, as the examples show:

  • འབྲི་ཡག་ “That (which) needs to be written,” “that (which) one writes”
  • ཕུལ་ཡག་ (Literary: འབུལ་ཡག་) “That (which) is to be offered,” “that (which) one offers”
  • མཇལ་ཡག་ “That (which) is to be visited,” “that (which) one visits”
  • བཟོ་ཡག་ “That (which) is to be built,” “that (which) one builds”
  • དཀར་ཡོལ་བཀྲུ་ཡག་དེ་ཚོ་ག་པར་ཡོད་རེད། “Where are the cups to be washed?”
  • ཅ་ལག་ཁྱེར་ཡག་དེ་ཚོ་ཕ་གིར་འདུག “The things (that have) to be taken are over there.”
  • ཕྱག་དེབ་ཕུལ་ཡག་(འབུལ་ཡག་)འདི་ཁྱེར་ཡོད་པས། “Have you brought the book that we’re going to present?”

2. The suffix also operates as a neutral nominalizer: it nominalizes the entire clause.

In this case, the suffix is not oriented toward any grammatical role and nominalizes the entire clause. From a syntactic point of view, the nominalized verb functions as a head noun and may be translated in English by a verb in the infinitive, by an -ing clause, a that clause, or even by a noun:

  • འབྲི་ཡག་ “(The fact of) writing”
  • ཕུལ་ཡག་ (Literary: འབུལ་ཡག་) “(The fact of) offering”
  • མཇལ་ཡག་ “(The fact of) visiting”
  • བཟོ་ཡག་ “(The fact of) constructing/construction”
  • དེབ་ཁྱེར་ཡག་བརྗེད་བཞག “I’ve forgotten to bring the book.”
  • སློབ་སྦྱོང་བྱེད་ཡག་དེ་གལ་ཆེན་པོ་རེད། “Studying is very important.”
  • དགོན་པ་ཆུང་ཆུང་མང་པོ་མཇལ་ཡག་འདུག “There are many small monasteries to visit.”

Only the syntactic context allows one to distinguish between the neutral nominalizer and the patient-centered nominalizer.
